abstract.t: This document describes the mechanism to provision the DHCPv4 services over the DHCPv6 protocol.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: During the transition from IPv4 to IPv6 the dual stack networks are common. In such networks either DHCPv4 or DHCPv6 servers are used by hosts to obtain configuration. In many cases, the host being configured with DHCPv4 protocol is separated from the DHCPv4 server by the IPv6 only network segment, while existing protocols to not allow for DHCPv4 to traverse IPv6 network.
This document describes extensions to DHCPv6 protocol to allow transmission of DHCPv4 traffic via DHCPv6 enabled network.

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: The assumption that DHCPv4 packets can be encapsulated by the DHCPv6 RELAY-FORWARD and RELAY-REPLY messages is fundamental for the extensions described in this document. Thus, if the DHCP4 client is separated from the DHCP4 server by the IPv6 network segment it is required that DHCP6 traffic is carried through this segment and that at least one relay agent resides on the route between the DHCP4 client and server.

figure.title: Network topology with DHCPv6 server handling DHCPv4 messages

section.t: The shows the sample network topology where the traffic from both DHCP4 and DHCP6 clients is directed to the same DHCP6 server. The relay agent conveys both v4 or v6 messages in RELAY-FORW message described in section 7.1 of RFC 3315, but in two different options. The v6 messages are conveyed in OPTION_RELAY_MSG as described in the RFC 3315 while the v4 messages are conveyed in the new option OPTION_DHCP4_RELAY_MSG defined in this document. This guarantees that relay agents and servers may easely differentiate the v4 and v6 traffic by simply looking at the type of the option being carried in the RELAY-FORW message.
Once the server has processed the message it sends back the response to the relay agent in the RELAY-REPL message described in section 7.2 of RFC 3315.

The topology presented above requires that not only is DHCP6 server capable to process DHCP6, but also DHCP4 traffic. Such hybrid implementations are common and in many cases can be created with a minimal effort if the particular code comprises shared libraries with DHCP4 and DHCP6 packets processing logic.

Another desired use case is to process the v4 and v6 messages on two distinct servers - DHCP6 server processing only v6 messages and the DHCP4 server processing only v4 messagess. The corresponding network topology has been shown on the .

figure.title: Network topology with DHCPv6 server handling DHCPv4 messages

section.t:
The v4 message is initiated by the DHCP4 client and is relayed by the Relay 1 in the same way as in the previous example. However, in this case the v6 and v4 messages are directed to different destinations. Relay 2 receives relayed v4 messages over IPv6 and relays them to the DHCP4 server using IPv4. Therefore, the following conditions MUST be met if the implementation supports this use case.
The relay agents MUST be configurable so as respective destinations can be specified for v4 and v6 traffic. The relay agent adjacent to the DHCP4 server MUST be able to relay incoming DHCP4o6 messages using IPv4. The relay agent adjacent to the DHCP4 server MUST be able to receive relayed DHCP4 traffic from the server and relay it using DHCPv6 RELAY-REPL as described above.
The former of the use cases described in this chapter MUST be supported by all implementations conforming to this specification. The support for the latter use case is optional.
